dialog_options.prompt: No. You want the orchard and the hazelnuts to yourself.
A group of bandits dart out from behind some underbrush.
No. You want the orchard and the hazelnuts to yourself.
No, and you convince the group to send the kids away.
Yes, and you convince the group to let the kids stay.
Watch the group all morning from a distance.
"This can't be real. I'm going back to sleep."
"Would you like to learn to play? I'm happy to teach you."
You lie down and begin to cry.
Leave as quickly as possible. You don’t want to risk becoming infected.
Keep your distance, but leave some resources for them.
Double back to avoid the group noticing you.
"I'm going to wait things out here."
"Would you like to learn to play? I'm happy to teach you."
"Hold on. I want to grab some things first."
Not quite. He gave information too quickly.
I’m happy to share my game play data for research purposes.

Keep your distance, but leave some resources for them.
Return to the group with the trio.
Introduce yourself to the family and help them.
The family chooses an item from your bag.
Start your way back to your friends.
Stay hidden and wait for them to pass.
"I'm going to wait things out here."
Take five minutes to gather some water and photos.
Join the trio and do not return to your friends.
Things might turn out okay. (Takes you to Year 1)
I’d prefer that my game play data not be used for research purposes.

Track the group and steal their resources at nightfall.

No. You are worried that the memory might upset her.

You go back inside to get your things.

dialog_scripts.text: There are days where you wonder how you’ve managed to stay alive. You roam the outskirts of what used to be thriving cities, scavenging for food and things you can use.
The two of you exchange stories throughout the afternoon. As the sun sets, Jeremy pulls out a harmonica from his back pocket.
You return to the group empty handed. You wonder how long you will be able to continue surviving.
You rub your eyes, yawn, and open up a textbook from one of your classes to get some homework done.

"I'm Jeremy from down the hall. Listen, you don't have much time! They're evacuating the building and asked me to tell everyone on this floor. A deadly flu has swept over the city, and you don't have much time to collect everything you need."

The children run off while one of your friends digs into your bag and pulls out your first aid kit. Luckily, your friend was a surgeon before the Georgia Flu pandemic, and he is able to stop the bleeding. You are extremely fortunate; if you had been kinder to the children, this would never have happened.

You glare at them. "Empty your bags, turn around, and leave. If you try to follow me, you will die." They look at each other, then dump out their backpacks and leave. You gather the useful items and food, put them in your backpack, and start to make your way back to your camp.
The group lets you stay for the night, but they ask you to leave the next day. You leave reluctantly.
Thank you!
"Where did you find these?" Jeremy asks. "Can you teach us how to forage for them like you do?"
The group lets you stay for the night, but they ask you to leave the next day. You leave reluctantly.

You feel as if you’ve made a good decision. 

You awaken in the middle of the night with one of the group members sitting on your chest and holding a knife to your throat.
Hello
Hello
You don't want to bring up bad memories, so you keep the photo a secret. You approach the group.
Hello
You continue walking, but wonder if you made the right decision. Lost in thought, you lose focus on your surroundings.

"It's a good thing I have you, Luli," you say to your imaginary companion. "Life would be lonely without you."

Luli remains quiet. You decide the last statement is untrue. Life is lonely either way.
"Thanks for hurrying. Before she left, the RA gave me some stuff. I can't possibly carry it all in addition to my own stuff."

As you look off into the distance, you swear you can see Luli bounding toward you, her ears flopping in the wind.

You close your eyes and never wake up. The authorities add you to the count of those who don’t survive the pandemic aftermath.

Inside the house, you find a rifle that miraculously still has bullets and an acoustic guitar. You want to take both back with you, but the youngest child is tired. You will have to carry her back, and you can only carry her and one other item.
Five years have passed since the Georgia Flu outbreak.
Welcome to ecopod developed by the UO Center for Applied Second Language Studies.
"Okay," Jeremy agrees. "But hurry!"

Charlie is so thankful that you’ve shared a memory that makes her think of her family and how life was before the Georgia Flu. She shows you a picture of her family that she has kept all this time. You share some hazelnuts that you collected with her. The group looks at the hazelnuts with wonder.
Thank you!
"Thanks for hurrying. Before she left, the RA gave me some stuff. I can't possibly carry it all in addition to my own stuff."
It is only then that you recognize Jeremy, a student who lived on the same floor as you did in the residence hall. He sees you and gives you a hug.
The next day, you lead the group on an outing to forage for wild edible plants. As you rummage through the underbrush, you find some candles.
You wake up, feverish and uncomfortable, a few times as the night wears on, but you don’t wake up at all come morning.
The group lets you stay for the night, but they ask you to leave the next day. You leave reluctantly.

When the sun goes down, you are so desperate to find your friends that you venture deep into the forest. Thanks to your tools, you are able to light the way and find a set of footprints. You notice something glimmering next to the footprints: a harmonica. Jeremy must have left this for you to follow!

You carry the young child back on your shoulders and carry the guitar in your hands.

Once back at camp, the group is excited that you found a guitar. Jeremy immediately picks it up to play. You accompany him on the harmonica.

You move to the edge of camp with the children and play your harmonica. The music reminds one of them of his older brother who also could play, and he shares everything he knows. "We were with the people who robbed you," he admits. "But we didn't like stealing, so we left."

You offer to read it for her. It’s a book that your mother used to read to you. You feel honored to create a memory for the child that is similar to your own growing up. The children fall asleep next to you.
On your way out the door, you glance at your desk. Maybe you should take something with you.
"I don't know much more than you do, but we HAVE to go. I’ll try to explain later. Are you ready?"
Hello
The two of you exchange stories throughout the afternoon. As the sun sets, Jeremy pulls out a harmonica from his back pocket.
You recognize Jeremy, a student who lived on the same floor as you did in the residence hall. You run toward the group, shouting elatedly. Jeremy sees you and gives you a hug.
Hello
You wait a few hours for the group to move along and then track them. As soon as the sun sets, you sneak into their camp and steal their backpacks. One of them wakes up and sees you.
Jeremy from down the hall must be crazy. You go back into your suite and grab your textbook to get some homework done.

However, you also feel regret for some of the things you have had to do to survive. The people you have had to hurt, leave behind, or even kill had friends and family - lives which could have been forever altered by your decisions. You worry that, in surviving, you may have lost something you will never regain.
As the year passes, you feel more thankful for your friends. Their company helps you feel less lonely, and you think about life before the Georgia Flu outbreak less often.
You sit beneath a tree and begin to read the novel. As you drift off to sleep, you feel strangely optimistic and begin to think that things may turn out okay.
You wonder if you could have helped in another way. You may have been too generous and exercised too little caution.
The Georgia Flu inadvertently settles into your lungs.  You get tired of doing homework and lay down.
The group lets you stay for the night, but they ask you to leave the next day.

You manage to drag yourself a few feet ahead, hide in some bushes, and fall asleep - cold, lonely, and regretful. You wish you had helped the family. After all, the bandits took everything you had anyway.

You open up the novel you found, and a picture falls out of it. You pick it up and think there is something familiar about one of the women in the photo. Maybe you should go back to the camp to see if they know anything about her.
Finally, the youngest stops crying. She admits, "We were with the people who robbed you, but we didn’t like stealing so we left."
After gathering your things, you return to the door to find that the woman is gone. You leave the residence halls anyway and realize your suitcase is becoming too heavy to carry.
Hello

You pull the picture from the book.

"Excuse me," you say as you approach her. "I believe this belongs to you."

You hold out the photo and she gasps in surprise.

“It’s a good thing I have you, Luli,” you say to your imaginary companion. “Life would be lonely without you.”

Luli remains quiet. You decide the last statement is untrue.
The next day, you lead the group on an outing to forage for wild edible plants.
On your way out the door, you glance at your desk. Maybe you should take something with you.
Hello
Thank you!

"There are different items at each location. Think through what you want to bring with you. Remember, you can only take ten things with you. Choose wisely. Good luck and stay alive! I hope I will see you again. Oh! If you see a woman named Charlie, tell her to meet me at the Pioneer Woman."
The Georgia Flu inadvertently settles into your lungs.  You get tired of doing homework and lay down.
Others in your group throw rocks at the children to get them to leave. The youngest cries and stumbles as they leave your camp. You wonder if sending them away was the right thing to do.

However, you notice another intersecting group of footprints. You wonder if your friends were following these footprints or the other way around. Either way, you follow the trail as best as you can. You are still exhausted from not eating for so long and eventually fall into a light sleep.

You lie down underneath a tree and begin to cry. Days later, you still have not moved. You know you should find some water, but you aren’t thirsty. Or hungry. You aren't even sad anymore. You don't care about anything at all.
You lie down underneath a tree and begin to cry. Days later, you still have not moved. You know you should find some water, but you aren’t thirsty. Or hungry. You aren’t even sad anymore.
A woman in the group named Charlie approaches you. You remember hearing about her on the day that you evacuated the city.
Now what?
You slowly reach for the knife in your pocket and slash the attacker across the face. You push him off of you, but another tackles you. As you hit the ground, you try to find your knife.

That night, you share the hazelnuts you have in your backpack with the trio. In exchange, they share some rabbit jerky they had prepared.

You use your backpack as a pillow and stare at the stars. You debate whether to return to your group with the trio. Although they have valuable skills, they will be more mouths to feed.
Inside the duffle bag, you find water, batteries, and a first aid kit.
"Where did you find these?" Jeremy asks. "Can you teach us how to forage for them like you do?"
Hello
"Where did you find these?" Charlie asks. "Can you teach us how to forage for them like you do?"
Hello

Along the way, you’ve found a dog collar that reminds you of your childhood pet Luli. You fasten it to the outside of your backpack and talk to Luli as if she were walking beside you. As you wander, you come upon a makeshift camp with about a dozen people.
Is anyone here?  Open the door!

"That's a picture of me with my mother!" she exclaims. The woman shares that her name is Charlie. She is so thankful that you’ve shared a memento from before her life the Georgia Flu. She invites you to sit down.
The next morning, you decide to leave the camp to forage for some food, and you let the children come with you. Along the way, you venture toward an abandoned house.

You carry the young child back on your shoulders and carry the gun in your hands.

Once back at camp, the group is excited that you found a rifle with bullets. Charlie wants to borrow it to see if she can hunt a rabbit for dinner, but you don’t want to share. After all, you found it.
Unknowingly, when you looked into the hallway, you touched the outside door handle that was contaminated with the Georgia Flu. You spread the germs into your eyes when you rubbed them.
You return to the door to find that Jeremy has left without you. You leave the residence halls anyway and realize your suitcase is becoming too heavy to carry.

You breathe deeply before standing up and revealing your hiding spot.

"There is a river over there. I used it this morning to wash," you interject into their conversation. The trio stare at you in disbelief.
Hello
You feel thankful for finding Jeremy and his friends, and you feel more like yourself than you have in a long, long time.
You make your way back to your friends. Upon returning to your camp, you are surprised to find no one there. You try unsuccessfully to follow footprints in the dirt.
You rub your eyes and go back to bed, snuggling deep into the covers so the blankets cover up your eyes.
You put on your medical gloves before you go over to help the family. You do not want to risk getting sick with the Georgia Flu.

When you play ecopod, information about your game play is collected and saved on our servers. Your data can help us research how to improve ecopod, but we won’t use it that way unless we have your permission. Please tell us how we may use your data by selecting one of the choices below. You may change your choice at any later time.

"My friends asked me to find an area with more resources than we have. I've been scouting out this area. Although there is water, there isn’t much food, and the water attracts larger predators. I'm going to continue moving east for a few days to find a better spot. Would you like to come with me?" The three agree to join you.

The attacker groans, and you look up to find your knife is in his chest. You kick the attacker away and make a run for it. When you think the attackers have stopped following you, you slow down to catch your breath and cover your tracks. Afterwards, you start to make your way back to your camp.

The kids are thankful you let them stay. They are cold and huddle up next to you, but the oldest regards you with skepticism. You imagine how hard their life must be. The children fall asleep next to you.
What do you do?
You return to the door to find that Jeremy has left without you. You leave the residence halls anyway and realize your suitcase is becoming too heavy to carry.
Hello
It takes you a moment to realize from where. The novel you picked up before evacuating the city had a picture as a bookmark. The woman in the group is one of the two in the picture!

"It's a good thing I have you, Luli," you say to your imaginary companion. "Life would be lonely without you."

Luli remains quiet. You decide the last statement is untrue. Life is lonely either way.
You wake up, feverish and uncomfortable, a few times as the night wears on, but you don’t wake up at all come morning.

You try your best to calm the children by talking gently to them.

The youngest begins to cry. The oldest crosses his arms in front of his chest and glares at you.
"You can see there are items at each location. Think about what you really need, because you can only carry ten items. Oh! And if you see my daughter Charlie, tell her I love her."
You lie down underneath a tree and begin to cry. Days later, you still have not moved. You know you should find some water, but you aren’t thirsty. Or hungry. You aren’t even sad anymore.
Your resistance to sharing leads the others in the group to wonder if you are still a contributing member of the group.

“It’s a good thing I have you, Luli,” you say to your imaginary companion. “Life would be lonely without you.”

Luli remains quiet. You decide the last statement is untrue.
On your way out the door you glance at your desk. Maybe you should take something with you.
Soon after meeting the family, you begin to cough. You feel a heat begin to radiate from your forehead. You have the tell-tale fever of the Georgia Flu.
You put your hands in the air. "I'm unarmed," you say loudly.
Hello
You sit beneath a tree to rest. As you drift off to sleep, you feel strangely optimistic.
The group looks at the hazelnuts with awe and wonder. “Where did you find these?” Jeremy asks. “Can you teach us how to forage for them like you do?”
Unknowingly, you touched the outside door handle when you looked into the hallway, which was contaminated with the Georgia Flu. You spread the germs into your eyes when you rubbed them.
"We only have a little bit of time to gather what we need, and I have to get my own things together, too. The RA did tell me that the items we need are all over campus."
"You don't have much time! A pandemic has swept over the city, and you only have a little time to gather your stuff."
What would you like to give them?
You kick the attacker off you and scramble for the rifle you had luckily hid under some brush before you fell asleep. The group starts to come after you, but quickly stop as you cock your rifle.
Hello
Hello
The next day, you lead the group on an outing to forage for wild edible plants.

You manage to wrestle him off your chest, but the two others move in to help their friend. The fight is three against one, and the odds aren't in your favor.

One of them stabs you multiple times in the stomach, and the other grabs your bag. All three dart off into the night.
Days later, you still have not moved. You know you should find some water, but you aren't thirsty. Or hungry. You aren’t even sad anymore. You don't care about anything at all.
Hello

"All right!" You interject. "That's enough." The interrogation stops. Sniffling, one of the children speaks up. "We were with the people who robbed you, but we didn’t like stealing. So we left." You convince the group to let the kids stay.

You lie down underneath a tree and begin to cry. Days later, you still have not moved. You know you should find some water, but you aren’t thirsty. Or hungry. You aren't even sad anymore. You don't care about anything at all.
Do you still want to collect items?
Hello
After gathering your things, you return to the door to find that the woman is gone. You leave the residence halls anyway and realize your suitcase is becoming too heavy to carry.
